fields.name: Giuseppe Verdi
fields.synopsis:
Giuseppe Fortunino Francesco Verdi (Italian: [dʒuˈzɛppe ˈverdi]; 9 or 10 October 1813 – 27 January 1901) was an Italian composer best known for his operas. He was born near Busseto to a provincial family of moderate means, receiving a musical education with the help of a local patron. Verdi came to dominate the Italian opera scene after the era of Gioachino Rossini, Gaetano Donizetti, and Vincenzo Bellini, whose works significantly influenced him.

In his early operas, Verdi demonstrated a sympathy with the Risorgimento movement which sought the unification of Italy. He also participated briefly as an elected politician. The chorus "Va, pensiero" from his early opera Nabucco (1842), and similar choruses in later operas, were much in the spirit of the unification movement, and the composer himself became esteemed as a representative of these ideals. An intensely private person, Verdi did not seek to ingratiate himself with popular movements. As he became professionally successful he was able to reduce his operatic workload and sought to establish himself as a landowner in his native region. He surprised the musical world by returning, after his success with the opera Aida (1871), with three late masterpieces: his Requiem (1874), and the operas Otello (1887) and Falstaff (1893).

His operas remain extremely popular, especially the three peaks of his 'middle period': Rigoletto, Il trovatore and La traviata. The bicentenary of his birth in 2013 was widely celebrated in broadcasts and performances.

fields.name: Will Todd
fields.synopsis:
Todd was born in County Durham, attended Durham School and joined the choir of St Oswald's Church, Durham under its choirmaster David Higgins. He went on to study music at the University of Bristol. He is a pianist and regularly performs with his trio, and this played a large role in one of his best-known works, his Mass in Blue.

Mass in Blue (originally entitled Jazz Mass) was commissioned by Hertfordshire Chorus and first performed at the Cambridge Corn Exchange in July 2003 with Will Todd at the piano. Todd's wife, Bethany Halliday, performed the soprano solo alongside the Blue Planet Orchestra and Hertfordshire Chorus, conducted by David Temple.

His work The Blackened Man won second prize in the International Verdi Opera Competition in 2002 and was later staged at the 2004 Buxton Festival. The Screams of Kitty Genovese, a piece of music theatre, has been produced at the Boston Conservatory and New York Musical Theatre Festival. His oratorio Saint Cuthbert, with a libretto by Ben Dunwell based on the life of the saint, has been performed and recorded by the Hallé Orchestra and Choir under Christopher Austin.

Among Angels was commissioned by the Genesis Foundation and was first performed by The Sixteen in Salzburg. Written for WNO Max, Sweetness and Badness was performed on a tour during autumn 2006. Whirlwind, commissioned by Streetwise Opera, was first performed at The Sage Gateshead.

Todd also went to the United States twice to work with high school students and put on a performance which he conducted. Most recently,[when?] he visited with students from the band and orchestra at Oyster River High School in Durham, New Hampshire.

fields.name: Peter Brathwaite
fields.synopsis:
Manchester born baritone Peter Brathwaite trained at Newcastle University, the Royal College of Music and the Flanders Opera Studio. As well as performing internationally, Peter is the creator of the multimedia recital Degenerate Music: Music Banned by the Nazis, he writes and presents for BBC Radio 3 and is working with Getty Publications on his first book.

Recent engagements: Joey in the world premiere of Kris Defoort’s The Time of Our Singing (La Monnaie, Brussels); world premiere of The Lost Thing, Martin Carter in Hannah Kendall’s The Knife of Dawn (Royal Opera House); Schubert’s Winterreise (London’s St John’s Smith Square); Britten’s TheFive Canticles (Leeds Lieder)

fields.name: David Shipley
fields.synopsis:
British bass David Shipley is a graduate of the Jette Parker Young Artists Programme at the Royal Opera House, the Guildhall School of Music & Drama and the Royal Academy of Music. In 2022 he will perform with companies including the Royal Opera House, Scottish Opera, and the BBC National Orchestra of Wales.

Recent engagements: Prince Tokmakov Ivan the Terrible (Grange Park Opera); Sarastro Die Zauberflöte (Glyndebourne); Sparafucile Rigoletto (Houston Grand Opera)

fields.name: Njabulo Madlala
fields.synopsis:
Njabulo Madlala studied at the Guildhall School of Music & Drama and at the Cardiff International Academy of Voice. In 2010 he won the Kathleen Ferrier Award. He has performed with companies including The Royal Opera, Bergen National Opera, English National Opera, English Touring Opera, Scottish Opera, Grange Park Opera and Opera Holland Park. Concert highlights include Beethoven’s Symphony No 9 with the Minnesota Orchestra and Mendelssohn’s Elijah with the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra.

Recent engagements: Prince Yamadori Madam Butterfly (English National Opera); Jim Porgy and Bess (ENO, Dutch National Opera, Theater an der Wien); Aswini Twin in Ravi Shankar’s Sukanya (ROH/LPO)

fields.name: Nadine Benjamin
fields.synopsis:
British soprano Nadine Benjamin is a charismatic and versatile artist who is equally at home on both the operatic stage and the concert platform. She was an ENO Harewood Artist and has performed with Scottish Opera, Birmingham Opera Company, Opera Holland Park, English Touring Opera and The Royal Opera. Nadine is a mentor, certified High Performance Coach and Mind Coach, and in 2015 founded her opera and mentorship programme ‘Everybody Can!’. She is an Ambassador for London Music Masters.

Recent engagements: Soprano solo New Dark Age (ROH); Laura (and cover Luisa) Luisa Miller (ENO); Amelia Un ballo in maschera (OHP)

fields.name: Marion Newman
fields.synopsis:
English, Irish, Scottish mezzo Marion Newman’s voice has been likened to ‘rich… like fine coffee sweetened with honey liqueur.’ (Mooney on Theatre). Marion has starred as Rosina and Carmen and has had leading roles in Canada’s most compelling new operas.

Recent engagements: Dr Wilson Missing (Pacific Opera Victoria); Mother Hansel and Gretel (Edmonton Opera); Messiah (Rhode Island Philharmonic Orchestra)

fields.name: Tom Randle
fields.synopsis:
Tom Randle began early studies in conducting and composition, but a scholarship to study voice soon meant a change in career direction and made his debut with English National Opera as Tamino in The Magic Flute. As a composer, his new opera Love me to Death was premiered as the final event at the 2018 Tête à Tête Opera Festival. This season, Tom Randle will sing the title-role in Il ritorno di Ulisse at the Longborough Festival Opera.

Recent engagements: Loki The Monstrous Child (Royal Opera House); Beethoven’s 9th Symphony (Yomiuri Nippon Symphony Orchestra); Mozart’s Requiem (Handel and Haydn Society)

fields.name: Meeta Raval
fields.synopsis:
Meeta Raval rose to prominence as a finalist in the 2011 BBC Cardiff Singer of the World. She is renowned for her romantic heroines, and has performed roles such as Leonora, Nedda, Cio-Cio-San, Liu and Donna Anna for companies including the Royal Opera, English National Opera, Glyndebourne, Opera North and Kazan Opera.

Recent engagements: Leonora Il trovatore (Zomeropera Alden Biese, Opera Oviedo); title role Gustav Holst's Savitri (Leeds Opera Festival); Liu Turandot (Dalhalla Festival Opera)

fields.name: Isabelle Peters
fields.synopsis:
British Soprano, Isabelle Peters, is an alumna of the Guildhall School of Music & Drama and Royal Northern College of Music. Isabelle was a Fellow at English National Opera for their 2019/2020 season and regularly collaborates with pianists to perform Art Song repertoire and to take part in music competitions. She looks forward to appearing in the Veronica Dunne Singing Competition later this year. 

Recent engagements: Berta The Barber of Seville (WNO); Dido Dido’s Ghost (Barbican/Dunedin Consort, Barbican Hall); Barbarina Le nozze di Figaro (Opera Holland Park); First Bridesmaid The Marriage of Figaro (ENO); Fiordiligi Cosí fan tutte, Pamina Die Zauberflöte (Waterperry Opera Festival); First Lady Die Zauberflöte (Garsington)

fields.name: Simon Crosby Buttle
fields.synopsis:
Simon was born in West Yorkshire and studied at the Royal Northern College of Music with Jeffrey Lawton.  Whilst there he was a recipient of the Anne Ziegler Award and was funded by the Countess of Munster Musical Trust.

Prior to joining WNO, Simon worked as a freelancer with Opera North and Scottish Opera working as a principal, cover and extra chorus in productions including Madama Butterfly, La Rondine, Eugene Onegin, Candide, Nabucco and Katya Kabanova.

Simon’s personal highlight at WNO so far was performing in one of his favourite operas, Tristan und Isolde. Since joining WNO Chorus in 2009 he has also performed roles in The Magic Flute, La traviata, The Cunning Little Vixen, Lohengrin, Manon Lescaut, Peter Pan, i Puritani, In Parenthesis, Macbeth, Madam Butterfly, Der Rosenkavalier, Khovanshchina and From the House of the Dead.

In concert, Simon has performed with many choral societies, in works including Puccini’s Messa di Gloria, Rossini’s Petite Messe Solennelle, Bruckner’s Te Deum, Lloyd Webber’s Requiem, Haydn’s Creation, Coleridge-Taylor’s Hiawatha's Wedding Feast, Haydn’s Nelson Mass and Goodall’s Eternal Light.

Away from WNO, Simon enjoys working with recording software, crafting and painting models, spending too many hours playing computer games and has a passion for anything Science Fiction or Fantasy.

fields.name: Parvathi Subbiah
fields.synopsis:
Venezuelan/Indian soprano, Parvathi Subbiah, is a former student of Mirella Freni and studied at her Centro Universale del Bel Canto Academy in Italy.   Previously she had studied singing at Oberlin Conservatory and the University of South California.  A respected academic, she completed her Doctorate in Venezuelan politics at the University of Cambridge last year.

Recent engagements: Violetta La traviata, Mimì La bohème (Aspen Music Festival); Sandrina La finta giardiniera, Mrs Coyle Owen Wingrave (University of Southern California); Geraldine in Barber’s A Hand of Bridge (Londrina Music Festival, Brazil); title role Suor Angelica (Emypyeran Ensemble in Cambridge); Violetta Act 3 La traviata (Figaro Opera Society in Venice)

fields.name: Zwakele Tshabalala
fields.synopsis:
South African born tenor Zwakele Tshabalala completed his studies at The Royal College of Music on full scholarship and is poised to become an important artist of the next generation. His recent debuts have included Sportin’ Life in Porgy and Bess for Theater an der Wien and Hot Biscuit Slim in Paul Bunyan for English National Opera. 

Recent engagements: Title role in the world premiere of Neo Muyanga’s Anansi (Dutch National Opera); Beethoven’s Symphony No 9 (World Economic Forum, Switzerland under Marin Alsop); Dominique You in Amy Beach’s Cabildo (Wilton’s Music Hall, London)

fields.name: Sian Meinir
fields.synopsis:
Sian Meinir was born in Cheshire then raised in Gwynedd. Sian is a graduate of Bangor University and the Royal Academy of Music with Kenneth Bowen.

She was a member of the Royal Opera House Chorus before joining the WNO Chorus in 2003. She was recipient of the 2007 Susan Chilcott Award. Her highlights at WNO include Margaret Wozzeck, Enrichetta I Puritani, Annina La traviata, Kate Pinkerton Madam Butterfly, Iseult of the White Hands Le Vin herbé.

Outside of WNO Sian is an Eisteddfod Chair Poet; translates songs for the National Eisteddfod, and is a vocal tutor and a national Adjudicator.

Recent engagements: Old Woman of Bala in the world premiere of Wythnos yng Nghymru Fydd (Opra Cymru); a national tour of her one-woman show, Dream of Gerontius at St Asaph Cathedral; Ffatri Llais/Voice Factory one-day workshops across Wales.

fields.name: Matthew Kofi Waldren
fields.synopsis:
Matthew Kofi was born in Geneva‚ of Anglo-Ghanaian descent‚ and studied at the Royal College of Music‚ Guildhall School of Music & Drama‚ and read music at Fitzwilliam College‚ Cambridge. He was a ‘Newcomer’ nominee in the International Opera Awards 2017‚ and held the ENO Mackerras Fellowship 2016-18.

Recent engagements: Conductor Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Un ballo in maschera‚ La traviata‚ La Rondine (Opera Holland Park); Don Giovanni, La bohème (Opera North); The Marriage of Figaro, Paul Bunyan (ENO)

fields.name: David Pountney
fields.synopsis:
Sir David Pountney was born in Oxford and studied at St John’s College, Cambridge. In a career spanning over 45 years he has been Director of Productions at Scottish Opera and English National Opera, Intendant of the Bregenzer Festspiele and Artistic Director of WNO from 2011-2019. David’s pioneering productions have won him Janáček and Martinů medals and Olivier Awards, while his original librettos have been set to music by Sir Peter Maxwell Davies and Elena Langer. He has also translated librettos into English from Russian, Czech, German and Italian. Previously made a CBE, David Pountney was knighted for services to opera in 2019. He has also been decorated with civilian honours by Austria, Poland and France.

Recent engagements: Librettist A Feast in the Time of Plague (Grange Park Opera); Director Les vêpres siciliennes, The Cunning Little Vixen, War and Peace (WNO); and his new production of The Ring (Lyric Opera of Chicago), sadly abandoned due to Covid-19.

fields.name: Abdul Shayek
fields.synopsis:
Abdul Shayek is Artistic Director of Tara Arts and the founding Artistic Director of Fio where he has directed Swarm, The Mountaintop and Death and the Maiden to critical acclaim. He is a former Creative Associate for National Theatre Wales and has freelanced with a range of organisations.

Recent engagements: A Final Farewell Tara Arts, Welsh tour of Orchard of Lost Souls with Fio, ENO’s Orpheus in the Underworld and Athold Fugard’s UK tour of The Island.

fields.name: Sarah Crisp
fields.synopsis:
Sarah Crisp trained at LAMDA. After graduating and working with NoFit State Circus, she joined WNO’s stage management team, later becoming a Staff Director in 2005. She directed the revival of Cavalleria rusticana & Pagliacci as part of WNO’s 70th birthday celebrations. In 2020/2021, she devised and directed Covid-19 compliant productions for the RWCMD.

Recent engagements: Staff Director The Barber of Seville, Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland, Dead Man Walking (WNO); Revival Director La traviata, Die Fledermaus, Madam Butterfly (WNO); Director Spring Operas 2021, The Telephone, The Medium (RWCMD)

fields.name: Loren Elstein
fields.synopsis:
Loren Elstein trained at NIDA in Sydney, where her design for Loot secured her the Australian Production Design Guild Award for Best Design and the WFF Grant for Excellence in Design 2013. An international designer for theatre, opera and film, since returning to the UK she has designed for productions at The Old Vic, Apollo Theatre and English Touring Opera.

Recent engagements: Designer Don Pasquale (WNO); Production Design La Traviata (Longborough Festival Opera); Unruhe (Theatre Trier, Germany)

fields.name: April Dalton
fields.synopsis:
April Dalton was brought up in Wolverhampton and trained as an associate with Birmingham Royal ballet. She studied Theatre Design at the RWCMD, winning the Costume Design Award. After graduating her work was shortlisted for The Linbury Prize for Stage Design. Upcoming work includes designs for Birmingham Royal Ballet.

Recent engagements: Costume Designer Dead Man Walking, The Consul, The Prisoner/Fidelio (WNO); Lucia di Lammermoor (Dorset Opera); Set & Costume Designer Albert Herring (RWCMD)

fields.name: Zoe Spurr
fields.synopsis:
Zoe Spurr is a theatre lighting designer whose work has been seen on the West End, throughout the UK and internationally. She won the 2019 Theatre and Technology Award Lighting Design for The Unreturning (Frantic Assembly UK Tour), Lightmongers’ ALD Award for New Talent in Entertainment Lighting and the OFFIE award for Lighting Design for Tiny Dynamite (Old Red Lion Theatre).

Recent engagements:Our Generation (National Theatre); Bonnie and Clyde the Musical (West End); Current Rising (Linbury Studio, Royal Opera House); Fantastically Great Women Who Changed the World (Kenny Wax Family Entertainment); Mast (Mayflower and UK Tour); Eugene Onegin, Georgiana (Buxton International Festival)

fields.name: Sebastian Frost
fields.synopsis:
Sebastian Frost trained at the Guildhall School of Music and Drama. He has been the Sound Designer for a unique and diverse range of hundreds of projects from London’s West End, Broadway and European theatre productions to installations, large scale public events, exhibitions, product launches and awards ceremonies.

Recent engagements:The Last Ship (UK, US, Canada); A Little Night Music (Opera North/Leeds Playhouse); 170 Days in Nanjing (Nanjing Opera); Memoirs of a Sailor (Kuwait National Theatre); Kiss Me Kate (WNO); Jekyll & Hyde (Old Vic); Queen Coal (Sheffield Crucible)

fields.name: Melody Squire
fields.synopsis:
American-born choreographer Melody Squire is known for creating visually stimulating work as well as her innate storytelling ability. Her versatility across dance genres makes her a choreographer in high demand, working extensively in film, television and theatre. As a performer, Melody has worked with numerous artists including Madonna, James Blunt, Shah Rukh Khan and pop promo for Beyoncé. Melody is the founder and artistic director of Sol Dans Company, a London based, award winning contemporary dance company.

Recent engagements: Choreographer for Fila, Selfridges, the Corrs, SYTYCD UK and Tiger Bay the Musical.

fields.name: Sarah Woods
fields.synopsis: Sarah Woods is a playwright, activist and educator. She is currently writing The Ruff Tuff Cream Puff Estate Agency with Boff Whalley, for Cardboard Citizens, and working with Dr Jane Goodall on a dramatization of her book In the Shadow of Man for BBC Radio 4. Sarah’s podcast series Power Out, about power and extinction, is available on BBC Sounds.

fields.name: Eric Ngalle Charles
fields.synopsis: Eric Ngalle Charles is a Cameroon-born Wales based writer, poet, playwright, actor and activist. He is currently a postgraduate student at Swansea University. Following the publication last year of his autobiography, I, Eric Ngalle, Eric was selected by Jackie Kay as one of the UK’s top ten BAME writers. He was recently the special guest at the African Festival of Emerging Writers, Cardiff Seren poetry Festival and his short film Eric Ngalle: This is Not a Poem is currently touring the UK.

fields.name: Tomáš Hanus
fields.synopsis:
Tomáš Hanus began his tenure as WNO Music Director in autumn 2016 receiving rave reviews from the start. His first season featured opera productions of Die Fledermaus and Der Rosenkavalier, concerts with the WNO Orchestra at St David’s Hall, Cardiff where he received a five-star review in The Guardian, and the prestigious Cardiff Singer of the World Competition. Tomáš returned to Cardiff in autumn 2017 with highly acclaimed productions of Khovanshchina and Janáček’s From the House of the Dead. As WNO Music Director, each season Tomáš will conduct orchestral concerts around Wales and England as well as taking the baton during opera seasons.

Outside the UK, in 2017/2018 Tomáš made his debuts at the Vienna State Opera with Rusalka, where he received an immediate re-invitation, and at the Zurich Opera with performances of Rite of Spring. In 2018/2019 Tomáš continues his strong relationship with Bayerische Staatsoper, Munich where he conducts a new production of The Bartered Bride and he returns to Opéra National de Paris for Tchaikovsky’s Iolanta. Past seasons Tomáš has conducted at the Dresden Staatskapelle, the Danish National Opera and Teatro Real Madrid.

As a symphonic conductor, Tomáš has conducted the London Symphony Orchestra, SWR Sinfonieorchester Baden-Baden, Czech Philharmonic, BBC Symphony Orchestra and at the Mostly Mozart Festival New York with the Festival Orchestra to name a few.

Born in Brno in the Czech Republic, he is recognised as one of their most exciting and important current conductors.

fields.name: Giacomo Puccini
fields.synopsis:
Giacomo Puccini[n 1] (22 December 1858 – 29 November 1924) was an Italian composer known primarily for his operas. Regarded as the greatest[1] and most successful proponent of Italian opera after Verdi, he was descended from a long line of composers, stemming from the late-Baroque era. Though his early work was firmly rooted in traditional late-19th-century Romantic Italian opera he later developed his work in the realistic verismo style, of which he became one of the leading exponents.

His most renowned works are La bohème (1896), Tosca (1900), Madama Butterfly (1904), and Turandot (1924), all of which are among the most frequently performed and recorded of all operas.

fields.name: James Southall
fields.synopsis:
James Southall is a conductor, pianist and coach with WNO. He trained at Queens’ College, Cambridge and the Royal College of Music where he studied with Roger Vignoles and John Blakely. He has conducted several leading opera companies and orchestras including English Touring Opera, Sinfonia Cymru, L'orchestra Haydn di Bolzano e Trento, Camerata Nordica and Opéra de Baugé. He has also been Assistant Conductor to Carlo Rizzi, Tomáš Hanus, Lothar Koenigs and Mark Wigglesworth. James won the Accompanist’s Prize at The Kathleen Ferrier Awards and has collaborated with Sir Bryn Terfel, Rebecca Evans, Elizabeth Watts and Ailish Tynan. He has given recitals at the Wigmore Hall and performed live on BBC Radio 3. Recent projects include directing two Menotti operas from the piano with the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama, Musical Director for the Mozart/da Ponte Trilogy workshop at La Monnaie, Brussels and Assistant Conductor for Schoenberg’s Moses und Aron at the Teatro Real, Madrid.

Recent engagements: Conductor Roberto Devereux, La traviata, Don Giovanni, Die Fledermaus, Le Vin herbé (WNO)

fields.name: Lindy Hume
fields.synopsis:
Lindy Hume has created major productions in Australia, New Zealand, across Europe and the UK, Sweden, and America. She has been Artistic Director of Opera Queensland, Sydney Festival, Perth International Arts Festival, Victoria State Opera, OzOpera, West Australian Opera and currently leads Ten Days on the Island, Tasmania and the Four Winds Festivals.

Recent engagements:Rigoletto (Seattle Opera); The Marriage of Figaro (New Zealand Opera); The Barber of Seville (State Opera South Australia)

fields.name: Caroline Chaney
fields.synopsis:
Caroline Chaney was born in Manchester and trained in ballet. After a degree in Education, she worked as an actor and puppeteer. She then worked in floor management for the BBC, stage management for WNO, the Royal Opera House and Opera North and Company management for WNO and Glyndebourne, before joining WNO full time as Staff Director.

Recent engagements: Director Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland,Rigoletto, The Magic Flute, Don Giovanni, Eugene Onegin, Associate Director Les vêpres siciliennes (WNO); Sweeney Todd (La Monnaie, Den Kongelige Opera | The Royal Danish Opera)

fields.name: Alicia Frost
fields.synopsis:
Alicia Frost is from Winnipeg and trained at The School of Toronto Dance Theatre, Laban and Royal Academy of Dance. She is on the faculty at Urdang and ArtsEd. She worked as an animateur for Rambert Dance Company for many years. Frost has worked in British opera as a freelance dancer, movement director, choreographer and assistant director. Her forthcoming engagements include Choreographer for The Magic Flute with Oxford Opera and Hansel and Gretel with Nederlandse Reisopera.

Recent engagements: Assistant Director Don Giovanni (Dorset Opera), Peter Grimes (WadOpera Nederlandse); Choreographer Paris and Helen (Bampton Classical Opera); Staff Director Roberto Devereux, La Cenerentola (WNO)

fields.name: Denni Sayers
fields.synopsis:
Denni Sayers is a choreographer and director working in opera and theatre. She has long-standing collaborations with many leading directors‚ including Francesca Zambello‚ Jonathan Kent‚ Niel Armfield‚ David Pountney and the late Nikolaus Lehnhoff. Sayers has also several staged BBC Proms, including The Water Diviner’s Tale, Dr Who proms and Ten Pieces proms.

Recent engagements: Choreographer Carmen, The Marriage of Figaro, Rigoletto (WNO); Carmen (San Francisco Opera); Manon Lescaut (Teatro alla Scala); Hänsel und Gretel (Wiener Staatsoper)

fields.name: Isabella Bywater
fields.synopsis:
Isabella is an award-winning director and designer of opera and theatre. She has designed sets and costumes for over 50 productions both in the UK and internationally. Her designs for A Midsummer Night’s Dream at the Mariinsky Theatre were nominated for multiple awards and the production won the prestigious Zolotov Sofit award for ‘Best Opera’ (2011). Isabella made her director and designer debut in 2013 with Gounod’s Faust at the Mariinsky Theatre. She is also a sculptor and studied Philosophy at Birkbeck, University of London.

Recent engagements: Director & Designer Suor Angelica, Il Tabarro, Gianni Schicchi (Oslo Opera); La bohème (San Diego Opera); Faust (Mariinsky Theatre)

fields.name: Ash J Woodward
fields.synopsis:
Ash J Woodward is an award-winning Video and Projection designer for live performance. He has designed and animated content for large scale shows on Broadway, in the West End, and around the world. His work includes 2D and 3D animation, cinematography, and visual effects. Ash also designs work for other live performance genres such as live music, exhibitions, and art installations.

Recent engagements: Can I Live (Complicité); The Beauty Parade (Wales Millennium Centre); Armadillo (The Yard); The Cunning Little Vixen (Royal Opera House) and Harry Potter and the Cursed Child (Palace theatre and worldwide)

fields.name: Elanor Higgins
fields.synopsis:
Elanor is a prolific Lighting Designer based in Wales; lighting productions for Theatre, Opera, Dance, Musicals and Children’s Theatre in all sizes of theatres and venues as well as site specific and found spaces. Her work has taken her throughout the UK and internationally, including Ireland, Spain and the Sydney Opera House. She is a graduate of the Royal Welsh College of Music and Drama where she returns as a guest lecturer and mentor in Stage Lighting and Scenography.

Recent engagements: Lighting Designer Rhondda Rips it Up (WNO); Eye of the Storm, The Ghost of Morfa Colliery, The White Feather, Halt (Theatr na nÓg); Pryd Mae’r Haf? Merched Caerdydd, Nos Sadwrn o Hyd, Hollti, Y Negesydd, Pridd (Theatr Genedlaethol Cymru)

fields.name: Leonardo Caimi
fields.synopsis:
Celebrated for his velvety tone and elegant musicality as well as his excellent acting, Leonardo Caimi has established himself as one of the most acclaimed tenors of his generation, singing at prestigious venues and festivals across the world, such as the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, Teatro alla Scala, the Teatro Real in Madrid, the Bavarian State Opera in Munich, Teatro Colón in Buenos Aires, Deutsche Oper Berlin and the Salzburg Festival.

Recent engagements: Count Danilo Danilovitsch The Merry Widow, Alfredo Germont La traviata (Teatro Lirico di Cagliari); Des Grieux Manon Lescaut (State Opera Plovdiv, Israeli Opera); Werther Werther (Polish National Opera); Don José Carmen (Oper Leizpig)

fields.name: Kezia Bienek
fields.synopsis:
British Mezzo-soprano Kezia Bienek trained at the Guildhall School of Music & Drama and the Opera School at the Royal College of Music. She has appeared at Wexford Festival Opera and the London Handel Festival and covered major roles at ENO, Scottish Opera and Glyndebourne, where she recently made her debut in both the Festival and Tour.

Recent engagements: Forester's Wife The Cunning Little Vixen, Second Lady The Magic Flute (WNO); Dorothée Cendrillon (Glyndebourne on Tour); Cornelia Giulio Cesare (Glyndebourne Festival); Beppe L'amico Fritz (Opera Holland Park)

fields.name: Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart
fields.synopsis:
Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart[a] (27 January 1756 – 5 December 1791), baptised as Joannes Chrysostomus Wolfgangus Theophilus Mozart,[b] was a prolific and influential composer of the Classical period. Despite his short life, his rapid pace of composition resulted in more than 800 works of virtually every genre of his time. Many of these compositions are acknowledged as pinnacles of the symphonic, concertante, chamber, operatic, and choral repertoire. Mozart is among the greatest composers in the history of Western music,[1] with music admired for its "melodic beauty, its formal elegance and its richness of harmony and texture".[2]

Born in Salzburg, in the Holy Roman Empire, Mozart showed prodigious ability from his earliest childhood. Already competent on keyboard and violin, he composed from the age of five and performed before European royalty. His father took him on a grand tour of Europe and then three trips to Italy. At 17, Mozart was engaged as a musician at the Salzburg court but grew restless and travelled in search of a better position.

While visiting Vienna in 1781, he was dismissed from his Salzburg position. He chose to stay in Vienna, where he achieved fame but little financial security. During his final years in Vienna, he composed many of his best-known symphonies, concertos, and operas, and portions of the Requiem, which was largely unfinished at the time of his early death at the age of 35. The circumstances of his death are largely uncertain and have thus been much mythologized.

fields.name: John Pinney | Alexander Morris | Pin-Striped Man

fields.synopsis:
The desire to broaden our horizons is a natural one, but for many, it is a necessity to improve on circumstances. However, the result of doing so often has unintended consequences. 

Through a series of six parallel storylines, Welsh National Opera’s new opera explores the highs and lows of migration.

Mayflower
Written by Sir David Pountney
The story of the group of settlers who sailed to America on the Mayflower 400 years ago, seeking freedom from religious persecution in Britain.

Treaty 6
Written by Sarah Woods
The story of a community fighting to save the land they are stewards of from environmental devastation and their reaction to the experience of inward migration, displacement and colonisation by British migrants. 

Flight, Death or Fog
Written by Edson Burton & Miles Chambers
House slave v field slave. Was one more privileged than the other? The story of Pero, an Afro-Caribbean slave in the ownership of a wealthy merchant family in 18th Century Bristol.

Birds
Written by Eric Ngalle Charles
To birds migration is a way of life. Movement from east to west and back occurs naturally, they cross lands, cross mountains for feeding grounds and return to their natural abode when the time is right. 

The English Lesson
Written by Sarah Woods
A group of refugees and asylum seekers gather to learn English in the country they have recently arrived in. But while the questions they learn to ask and answer seem simple they reveal a more difficult reality.

This is the Life!
Written by Shreya Sen-Handley
A humorous look at the experience of Indian doctors in the NHS. In 1968, two young practitioners, invited by the British Government to build the new National Health Service, find themselves reviled and rejected, despite the assurances given of the “good life” awaiting them
fields.tagline: We spread our wings but what are the consequences?

fields.synopsis:
Wedding preparations are underway for Lieutenant Pinkerton of the United States Navy, who has taken out a ‘999-year’ lease on a house. Anticipating the arrival of his young bride-to-be, known as Madam Butterfly, Pinkerton is reassured by the ‘marriage-broker’ Goro that both the lease and the marriage contract have convenient exit clauses. He breezily shares his world view over a pre-wedding drink with his compatriot the American Consul Sharpless, who is concerned that the girl Butterfly recently visited the American Consulate and appears to be taking the marriage seriously. His advice to proceed with caution goes unheeded by the infatuated Pinkerton.

Butterfly (Cio Cio San) arrives, surrounded by friends and relations, eager to meet her new husband. She candidly reveals to Pinkerton and Sharpless the facts of her life so far. Her family has lost everything. Her father had committed suicide, so she entertains as a ‘hostess’ to support her impoverished mother. She is exactly 15 years old. Privately, Butterfly shares her most treasured possessions with Pinkerton, confessing that, in order to please her husband, she has been secretly adapting to his American way-of-life and beliefs.

The marriage ceremony takes place with efficiency, but the celebrations are interrupted by the Bonze, Butterfly’s feared uncle, who confronts her about her secret visits to the mission and the American Consulate. Furious, the Bonze publicly condemns Butterfly for betraying her community and culture. Her shocked family and friends, apart from the servant Suzuki, denounce and shun her. Pinkerton comforts the abandoned Butterfly. The newlyweds make love under the stars.

Three years have passed. Butterfly and Suzuki are still living in Pinkerton’s house and have run out of money. Convinced that Pinkerton will return, Butterfly has turned down several marriage proposals from the wealthy Yamadori.

Sharpless has had a letter from Pinkerton asking him to break the news to Butterfly that he is planning to return, but that Pinkerton does not want to see her.  She refuses to listen. When Sharpless tries to persuade her to accept Yamadori, she says death would be preferable and reveals she has had a son by Pinkerton. Sharpless leaves, promising to let the child’s father know. The harbour cannon is heard, signaling the arrival of Pinkerton’s ship. Her devotion vindicated; Butterfly celebrates with Suzuki before settling down to await his arrival in a night vigil.

The next morning Butterfly is still waiting. Suzuki persuades her to sleep as Sharpless returns with Pinkerton and his real American wife, Kate. They ask for Suzuki’s help in breaking the news to Butterfly that they want to adopt the child. Faced with the reality of his actions, Pinkerton gives Sharpless money to pay for the child and leaves.

Butterfly wakes, to be confronted by a stranger who makes her afraid. Comprehending that this woman is Pinkerton’s wife, she agrees to give up her son on condition that Pinkerton comes in person to fetch him. She says goodbye to her young son and, using the weapon her father used before her, she kills herself. Pinkerton returns to find Butterfly’s lifeless body.
fields.tagline: Honeymoon hope turns to betrayal and despair

fields.synopsis:
A young Japanese woman, Cio-Cio-San (Madam Butterfly), has agreed to an arranged marriage with Lieutenant Pinkerton of the United States Navy. She takes the marriage seriously and falls in love, while he sees it simply as an amusing diversion during his posting to Japan.

Leaving his bride behind him, Pinkerton is gone for three years, during which Cio-Cio-San is reduced to penury and gives birth to his child. Sharpless, the American consul, breaks the news to her that Pinkerton has returned, but with a new, American wife.

When they hear about the child, Pinkerton and Kate decide that they should adopt him. In despair, knowing that they will be able to look after him better than she can, Butterfly takes a last farewell of her son and kills herself.

Joachim Herz’s Madam Butterfly has been with us for over three decades and with good reason. It’s a classic, traditional staging of this much-loved opera. While being completely faithful to the composer’s intentions it also critiques imperialism to powerful effect. Each scene looks like a sepia photograph through which we glimpse a vanished world.
fields.tagline: Cio-Cio-San marries, then falls in love with, US Navy Lieutenant Benjamin Pinkerton – with ultimately tragic consequences

fields.synopsis:
Opera’s ultimate seducer is back and he’s behaving very badly. The charismatic Don Giovanni seduces his way around Europe, taking what he wants and living for lust, without conscience. When one of his conquests ends in murder, it looks like his luck is about to turn. He finds himself on the run, pursued by disgruntled ex-lovers, fiancées and a force from beyond the grave. But when he refuses to show remorse, his past catches up with him and leads to his ultimate demise.

Based on the legend of Don Juan, Welsh National Opera’s production is set during the Spanish Golden Age. Mozart reflects both comedy and tragedy brilliantly in the score, including the ‘Catalogue’ aria detailing Giovanni’s list of 2065 lovers, the sparkling ‘Champagne’ aria and the high drama of the heart-stopping finale.
fields.tagline: Playing with fire will burn you in the end

fields.name: Madam Butterfly through a 21st century lens
